section.text: Good morning. Thanks for taking my question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Devin McDermott", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "b6bca61f-0c70-4dcd-8152-70d550cdcb02", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "632c523e-0582-482f-9889-7ddf2f912d79", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "3ca2b8d8-8e35-4a75-9547-f93107c832ee", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: So there are very strong results this quarter in the Downstream business and you called out throughput, volume and mix as some of the factors there, but I wondering if you talk a little bit more detail about some of the drivers here, and then just more broadly, there's a lot of moving pieces in the macro picture at the moment, demand, SPR draws, China reopening, the EU embargo on Russian crude just to name a few. I was wondering if you talk a little bit more about your outlook for refining as we head into next year as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Devin McDermott", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "cf75b8f1-f93c-4beb-ac91-3195f1144547", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Sure, why don't I take the first question and maybe give you the the macro. So if you look overall at our energy products business, obviously it was a really strong quarter. That was really from our perspective, led by the volume increases we saw. So we had record North American throughput, we had across the globe, best results on throughput that we had seen since 2008. And so, if you look at the earnings bridge in terms of what happened quarter-to-quarter that was worth almost $1 billion kind of improvement as a big driver in the results for energy products.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "aeb4bcce-d2b0-4ad1-bacf-25a16b924e47", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: If you then look at what's going on in margins, obviously margins softened in the quarter. They still remain well above what the 10-year average would be. If we look at those softer margins, they were really driven by downward pressure on gasoline margins due to lower than usual summer demand. Specifically in the U.S. diesel demand is continuing to be strong.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "aeb4bcce-d2b0-4ad1-bacf-25a16b924e47", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: We then had some offsets to that pressure that we saw on margin, and specifically if you look at some of the positive offsets we saw, we saw some favorable timing driven impacts. We try to separate this so you can kind of see it separated. Part of that was just mark-to-market on our open derivative portfolio that was worth about $250 million favorable impact in the quarter. Other price timing impacts were worth about $600 million favorable impact in the quarter. That was really driven by derivatives that we use to ensure ratable pricing of refinery crude runs.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "aeb4bcce-d2b0-4ad1-bacf-25a16b924e47", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: So if you put that to the side, we delivered about $5 billion in earnings outside of those price timing benefits in the quarter. And in addition to the other offsets for softening refining margins, we saw very strong aromatics margins, we did a good job on revenue management, so we saw a positive benefits there. And then overall, I would say, end-to-end supply-chain optimization, right, both through procurement and logistics and trading benefits on top of that. That's really embedded in the base business, and so we expect to see benefits out of those areas. They're not always ratable every quarter but if you look over time, those benefits clearly accrue to the business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "aeb4bcce-d2b0-4ad1-bacf-25a16b924e47", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Yeah, and I'll just add, Devin, maybe a couple of points on-top of what Kathy just explained. If you step back, you will recall that we, in 2018, came up with the value chain concept that we're using in the Downstream and really looking to optimize from crude coming in the gate all the way to products being delivered at our customer's doorstep. And the work the organization has been doing to optimize that value chain has resulted in additional value. I think it continues to make that business much more robust than what I would say the industry average is.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "49853461-c580-4071-ac8b-8237dbf7a0ac", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Kathy mentioned that the trading which has become an integral part of that value chain optimization step. And then I would and finally that a lot of work has been going into making sure that we are positioning those facilities in our Downstream and our refineries to be robust to an evolving demand landscape, and so if you look at where we are investing in refining, it's for sites that have integrated chemicals, lubricants and fast growing clean fuels business, and we think that gives us a structural advantage versus broader industry.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "49853461-c580-4071-ac8b-8237dbf7a0ac", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: This has been -- is and always has been a thin margin business. And so you typically scratch through the thin low periods which last very long times and then take advantage of some of the highs. And as a result of that thin margin business, if you look over time, certainly in the West, refining capacity has been on the decline. We actually showed a chart last quarter and again this quarter that shows that drop in refining capacity.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "49853461-c580-4071-ac8b-8237dbf7a0ac", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: If you look at some of the windfall taxes that are being talked about within Europe, that's going to put additional pressure on refining margins. So, there is certainly a scenario after this as we continue to see under-investment in refining, continue to see that capacity coming out of the market, and then depending on the build side of the equation, how much capacity gets built-out in the Middle East, we could see tight markets for some time to come.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "49853461-c580-4071-ac8b-8237dbf7a0ac", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Of course, we don't plan for that. We plan for thin margins and very tough conditions, and then hope for the best.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 5, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "49853461-c580-4071-ac8b-8237dbf7a0ac", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Great. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Devin McDermott", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "dc3e0e55-e175-41dc-b8c5-bac8cec3c147", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Hi. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for taking our questions.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeanine Wai", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "2afa0ef8-07b4-4719-93ab-b1a018b17c56", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Barclays"}

section.text: Good morning, Jeanine.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "4700f192-0c82-4030-b5e6-c1bb33baac16", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Good morning, Darren. Our first question and only question that I have here is on the balance sheet and cash returns. So, I guess, gross debt-to-cap now is just below the target range, cash is now at $30 billion, which is at the top-end of I believe that $20 billion to $30 billion level that you cited before that you want to maintain over time. So, I guess what are the implications on the trajectory of the buyback and how are you really viewing the trade-off between potentially accelerating buybacks sooner rather than later, given just the mechanical synergies with the dividend, and then just being more aggressive on dividend increases. And there was a nice bump announced this morning to the dividend. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeanine Wai", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "5017bfbb-09e6-4402-81a7-7de569fccc65", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Barclays"}

section.text: Sure. So first of all, I'd say our capital allocation priorities continue to be consistent. And we're executing well against that. We've got to continue to make sure we're investing in the business. It's a long-cycle business, and that consistency is really critical. We look for accretive acquisition opportunities, we're pretty disciplined in that area and you've obviously seen us more recently looking to execute a number of divestitures and what's been a pretty good market for that activity.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "76fc22d9-d655-498e-b37b-9eb1d76978ce", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: We are really focused on ensuring that we've got a fortress balance sheet that gives us all the firepower and flexibility that we need to operate through the cycles and be really prepared for the next downturn, and then we're also really focused on ensuring that we're sharing our success with shareholders. We're trying to get that balance right. You obviously referenced the fact that we increased our quarterly dividend by $0.03. So, that will be reflected in the fourth quarter dividend coming up here shortly. We're in the process of executing a $30 billion -- up to $30 billion share repurchase program through 2023, we are on track to get $15 billion of that program done by the end of the year. We did about $10.5 billion in share repurchases through the third quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "76fc22d9-d655-498e-b37b-9eb1d76978ce", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And if you look across the year, that would put us at $15 billion in dividends and about $15 billion in share repurchases. So I'd say both a pretty balanced return to our shareholders, and I think that puts us pretty well ahead of peers in terms of returning excess cash to shareholders. So we are mindful of our cash balance. We ended the quarter at about $30 billion. It is possible that our cash balance is going to float up a little bit from there depending on what the market environment continues to look like, and we will continue conversations with our Board about the share repurchase program. But right now, we're just continuing to execute our plan.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "76fc22d9-d655-498e-b37b-9eb1d76978ce", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Great. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeanine Wai", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "9761c7b9-8b92-43b9-bc48-b2e694fc3529", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Barclays"}

section.text: Thank you, and good morning, everybody. Darren, I wonder if I could just ask you to paint a kind of big-picture issue. You, I think, and a number of your peers met recently with the administration relating turn a number of things. I mean, I think the only folks are probably not happy with your results this morning may be the administration. Can you share any thoughts you had about some of the risks presented by legislators around things like export bans on products, things of that nature, not least given how strong your Downstream profitability was this morning?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Douglas Leggate", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "bc02dc42-2440-4a7e-8ed6-3b102235f999", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lynch"}

section.text: Yeah, good morning, Doug. I'm going to probably pass-on trying to predict where different governments or administrations here in the U.S. are going to go with respect to policy. We've been very explicit. I think me along with many of the peers in the industry around what I would say are the mechanics and the fundamentals of our industry and how it works and the implications for some of the policies being considered.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "7b0c6272-2043-4786-a3ac-067706fe0d54", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And I would say that on the short-term, it may solve a political problem, but it will carry all the policies that we have heard people talking about export bans, particular windfall profit tax. Those will carry significant long-term negative consequences. And it's just a question of, I think, how they balance out the political equation versus what I would say are some of the fundamentals.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "7b0c6272-2043-4786-a3ac-067706fe0d54", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: For me personally and for the company what I would say is, I feel like we're well-positioned. Obviously it would be disadvantaged to the industry but I think within that disadvantage we would find, because of our footprint, because of our diversification, ability to position ourselves competitively with whatever policy comes down the road. And so our focus is really making sure people understand what the potential consequences of some of these policies are being considered.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "7b0c6272-2043-4786-a3ac-067706fe0d54", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And then in parallel with that, obviously, staying very focused on what I think the root cause or the issue here is making sure that people all around the world and here in the U.S. get affordable and reliable energy. We recognize the pain that high prices cause. Unfortunately, the markets that we're in today is a function of many of the policies and some of the narrative that's floated around in the past. And we're basically have been working to make sure that when needed, when the products were required which we anticipated, you'll recall back in 2020, we made the point that the industry is under-investing, we continue to lean in into the investments to spend at a rate higher than the rest of industry so that when the call came, we would be there to answer.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "7b0c6272-2043-4786-a3ac-067706fe0d54", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And I think the results you've seen here in the third quarter is exactly that. Those investments are paying off, we've grown our production both in the Upstream and are growing our production in the Downstream Refining business with the expansion in Beaumont and then a real focus on reliability and high throughput. And so, we keep trying to reiterate that we are doing what we can within the boundaries of what's available to us today, and then longer-term, we are making the investments that's good for the administration's constituents and good for our business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 5, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "7b0c6272-2043-4786-a3ac-067706fe0d54", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Pleased to hear the answer, Darren. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Douglas Leggate", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "c293425e-6d04-44b2-a01e-afb112aacf97", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lynch"}

section.text: You bet.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "3c8cad5c-b0c0-4065-8cfe-ccdf88ddae87", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Thank you very much, and good morning. Darren, I would love your perspective on M&A and just how you see that fitting into the go-forward framework and specifically around Upstream consolidation but also low-carbon consolidation as you said that you want to grow that business over-time to be the size of the refining and chemicals business. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Neil Mehta", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "06b1ee74-2556-4e00-984c-8ec42a1cc2cb", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Sure, yeah, good morning, Neil. As you know, we've talked about this over the years quite a bit and I would tell you that the whole M&A space and divestments space is something that we are constantly working. Obviously, our strategy, which you've seen us execute here over the last several years is buy low, sell high. That's kind of what we're doing. We laid out a divestment program but we took our time, we're patient waiting for market conditions to develop. That would favor us as sellers and that's what you've seen transacting here. Likewise, as we look at acquisitions and opportunities constantly in the market, thinking about that looking-forward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "0dbb0dad-71b0-47d4-b342-9eb696789614", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: But we've got to find opportunities where we can see a clear synergy and develop a clear competitive advantage so that we bring some unique value to the transaction. We're evaluating and looking at that in our traditional businesses. I think with time those will show up, but we'll be very selective and strategic around that. And I would say, we'll do it when the market conditions our favorable for doing that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "0dbb0dad-71b0-47d4-b342-9eb696789614", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: On the low-carbon solutions, I think longer-term, the concepts sounds good in terms of M&A. But I would just put that in the context. This is a very immature market and so there aren't a lot of established businesses out there today that are -- have what it takes to be successful in this space. If you think about starting a industry from scratch, and what's required in terms of policy, regulation, investment, connecting all the different pieces of a brand-new value chain, that's a complicated equation, and fortunately, one that we think plays to our strengths. And the recent deal that we announced with CF Industries, for us really demonstrated that in terms of the complexity of putting together each element of that value chain to successfully come up with the deal that's value-accretive and generates profits, and it's good for the planet, it's good for our shareholders.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "0dbb0dad-71b0-47d4-b342-9eb696789614", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And so, I don't know how much -- we'll see how that develops. I would think in the M&A space, we may, over time, see opportunities that we can uniquely leverage. And then we'll bring those into portfolio when it makes sense to do that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "0dbb0dad-71b0-47d4-b342-9eb696789614", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Yes, sir.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Neil Mehta", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "0e458697-1863-4f7e-9b98-ead886bbfdd4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Good morning. Darren, I appreciate all the disclosure around the CF Industries project. I was wondering if you could talk about -- it probably comes as no surprise to anybody that you announced this shortly after the IRA was passed. But also, could you talk about what needs to happen on the policy side to kind of improve that abatement curve and kind of move more projects along, and then also, I think in the prepared remarks, you mentioned that there is still some hurdles with permitting, and the love. Do you see that at the local level, state level, and where those might be?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Richardson", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "af87aa99-0322-456e-b026-fad27967aebb", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: And then finally, if you could just address returns. How should investors think about the returns available on these projects considering kind of policy and some of the risks around that versus some of the more conventional Upstream or Downstream projects. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Stephen Richardson", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "af87aa99-0322-456e-b026-fad27967aebb", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Sure. Justin, yeah, I mean -- let me start with the first point you made around the timing of that. Well, certainly the IRA contributed to the value proposition there, I would say that that project and that deal was being worked well before that, and would work with the existing policy. It's been enhanced with the new policy obviously. And what I would just say with respect to what that IRA does, it essentially opens the aperture in terms of the CO2 that can be cost effectively captured or avoided.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "7270ed70-1fe8-47cb-95cb-33f8c506ba27", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And if you think about the challenges associated with economic projects to capture and sequester CO2, really important variables in that would be the concentration of the CO2. The more dilute the CO2 stream, the more expensive the capturing step. And so you need greater incentives to catch more -- to capture more streams. And so the IRA allows you to more economically pursue more dilute streams, so that opens up the opportunity space there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "7270ed70-1fe8-47cb-95cb-33f8c506ba27", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Another really important variable is the distance to sequestration and the transportation cost of moving CO2 there. And so the further away you are from those sources are from the storage sites, the higher the cost. And again, the IRA helps with that space. And then obviously, there's some incentives for hydrogen, and additional incentives for direct air capture. So, I think directionally, those things are going to help. But I would also say that to achieve the ultimate objective and driving emissions down to net-zero, you're need to capture a lot of dilute streams and the cost will be a lot higher and so we're going to find additional incentives for that, whether it be through market forces and markets developing for CO2 or additional policy.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "7270ed70-1fe8-47cb-95cb-33f8c506ba27", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: With respect to what else has to happen, obviously, we're at the very early stages of this project where we've got the economic incentives laid out. We have a path forward, but there's a lot to be done. We've got to get permits for storing the CO2, we've got some extensions to put on to pipelines. So there's other regulatory permitting steps that we have to take and the government -- we're working with the government to make sure that we can do that effectively so that we can expedite the project to get it online and start reducing those emissions. That's the equivalent of 700 -- taking 700,000 cars off the road. So it's a fairly significant project in and of itself.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "7270ed70-1fe8-47cb-95cb-33f8c506ba27", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: From a return standpoint, what I would say is, and we've talked about this before, we're insisting that the work we do here, that we position ourselves competitively versus the rest of industry, and the thinking being that whatever incentive is required for the marginal player out there to capture and store CO2 or develop biofuels are hydrogen, that we will leverage our advantages to drive a higher return, and to make sure that the projects that we bring into the portfolio are competitive in our portfolio. And that's exactly what we're doing, and CF Industries is an example of that an accretive project that's competitive in our portfolio that makes us money while reducing CO2.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 5, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "7270ed70-1fe8-47cb-95cb-33f8c506ba27", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And I would say, there are more opportunities like that out there, and the thing that Dan is doing in his low-carbon solutions business is looking for the opportunities where we can bring something unique to bear, and therefore drive above-industry average returns, and we feel pretty good about the size of that opportunity set.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 6, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "7270ed70-1fe8-47cb-95cb-33f8c506ba27", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Richardson", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "40e98bc6-7fd7-45c5-a561-b555e41437f2", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: You bet.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "9d5bb53f-bda3-498f-90ad-264d00c9a1c8", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Good morning, everyone. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Sam Margolin", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "9db426d5-0126-42df-a8e7-a40c7da77dbb", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "915eaafd-aa4e-41fd-b77f-1300b2b519d6", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "6c02ed0d-0cd1-4b0b-a9da-c4ab86d2af1a", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: My question is about your gas realizations which are a huge driver on the quarter. Would you characterize those as contractual or more optimization driven, and then this is an addendum, but I think the seasonality of the gas market has changed a little bit because Europe has very high demand in the summer now because of a storage imperative, and so I wonder if you see that as a structural change to the global gas market, and if it means anything for your investment prerogatives on the LNG chain or even in the U.S. within gas because we're gonna be exporting a lot. So that's the question. Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Sam Margolin", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "20d24307-4057-422a-9096-1f53fa4d82e9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Yeah, that's fine. I'll jump in and Darren can add if he has anything. Overall, if you look at our results, we saw strong gas realizations but we have an overall portfolio that 60% gas, 40% LNG. The LNG tends to be tied to crude related prices with a three to six month lag. So we're seeing the benefit of that lag now kind of coming through our results, and that really came through in the quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "87f6846e-7215-4cd2-8194-9b6d32672bae", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Overall, from a demand perspective, you're obviously seeing a really tight market. We saw in Europe, the building of inventory and how that has driven prices in Europe building up inventory ahead of the winter, and so structurally, we would say there's going to continue to be a tight market until supply and demand comes into equilibrium. And that -- there's only two ways that happens, either more supply or reduced demand. And supply, especially supply of LNG does take time to bring online. It isn't something that is, just a stick that can be turned on overnight. The market is obviously responding to that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "87f6846e-7215-4cd2-8194-9b6d32672bae", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: We obviously have projects that are bringing more LNG online. Darren mentioned Mozambique Coral, the project reaching first gas production. Recently, we've got Golden Pass which is going to be coming online in 2024. So we have investments that will bring more capacity online, and the industry obviously, is responding to that, but it is going to take some time. So I'd say as we look at that seasonality, we're always mindful of what's happening in terms of inventories and when inventories are being built or being drawn and what that means in terms of near-term market conditions. And so, it's something we always keep an eye on.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "87f6846e-7215-4cd2-8194-9b6d32672bae", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Yeah, I would just add, Sam, so once we get through this period where we're building inventories, we're short in supply and therefore you've kind of lost some of that seasonality that once we get to more of a balanced position, which I think is couple -- three years out, frankly, we'll start to see that seasonality show back up again when we're back in more stable markets.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "5e02684e-eb0d-403f-93af-186ab416f2af", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Longer-term, our view on gas has always been that gas is going to play a critical role in world economies for quite some time. And initially, it will go into power generation and back out coal. That's one of the big benefits of gas today. For longer-term, as we continue to address emissions and the energy system transitions, gas can be used for ammonia and hydrogen along with carbon capture. And so you can find, you can move into what I would say, a low emissions -- even lower emissions fuels, and address the CO2. And I think gas is going to play an important role in that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "5e02684e-eb0d-403f-93af-186ab416f2af", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: So I think our view hasn't really changed that there's going to be a fundamental need for gas for quite some time, and we're positioning ourselves to make sure that the portfolio of projects that we developed bring on natural gas on the left-hand side of the cost of supply curve. We going to continue to be focused on making sure that we're competitive under any scenario -- price scenario that we can envision out there. So that's how we're thinking about. That hasn't really changed, frankly.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "5e02684e-eb0d-403f-93af-186ab416f2af", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Thanks so much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Sam Margolin", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "76bde6dc-f14e-40e3-aaa2-841fd287631c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: You bet.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "ba954468-1205-451a-a10c-6ec1c89d11de", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Hey. Thanks for taking my questions. Maybe just one quick clarification before I ask my question, which is the dividend raise you used to do, I think with 1Q earnings, the past couple of years you've done with 3Q earnings. So is that a shift of timing or just any comment on that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jason Gabelman", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "4c929fd7-be02-47a8-8eb5-4038615705f4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen and Company"}

section.text: And then my question is just on the chemicals outlook. As you mentioned, there has been some weakening in the market. Just wondering, broadly, how you see that market evolving in the next 6 to 12 months supply, additional supply coming online and additional demand weakness or will things get tighter? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jason Gabelman", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "4c929fd7-be02-47a8-8eb5-4038615705f4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen and Company"}

section.text: Yeah, I'll take that quick question on dividend. We would have raised the dividend at the same time last year. One of the things I would mention is this is the 40th consecutive year where we've had an annual dividend increase, but we don't have a specific timing determined in any given point of the year in terms of when we make this decision. We look at it over time. We're obviously focused on having a competitive, sustainable, growing dividend over time, we know how important it is to shareholders, and roughly 48% of our shareholders are consumers and we know those people are very much focused on the dividends.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "b9fc60b5-5454-44ff-a574-2c3da79192bf", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Yeah, chemical is just -- as you mentioned, third quarter, we talked about softer demand. We really saw that as a consequence of the COVID lockdowns in China. We're very aware of some of the impacts that COVID is continuing to have in China, and that's going to be a big determinant of what we see happening in margins and kind of supply-demand balances going out in time. It's just how well China recovers from that and how quickly they can move out of these periods of lockdown and get direct current economic activity moving back again.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "7bc1b7e8-4eec-46af-94f9-5cebe81d26a4", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: I think as you move outside of China, which is obviously dominates demand out in Asia, and move more West into the U.S. and Europe, I think Europe, obviously with some of the energy challenges that they're facing are going to have much slower economic activity than would be historical. So, I expect to see some demand impacts coming from there. And then in the U.S., I would just say it's kind of -- I would just characterize it more as uncertainty. I think some of the softness that we saw in the third quarter was driven by inventory draw for many of our customers, and we typically see that when there is uncertainty about where the future is going, positioning themselves for, eventualities and making sure that they are covering themselves for potential downside.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "7bc1b7e8-4eec-46af-94f9-5cebe81d26a4", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: So, I think it's tough to tell. We'll have to see how the fourth quarter plays out, but in the short-term, certainly -- and we see inventories coming down quite a bit, and then longer-term, it'll will be a function of economic activity, obviously.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "7bc1b7e8-4eec-46af-94f9-5cebe81d26a4", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And then just one other thing I'd mentioned, we certainly see some industry supply that's coming on in the fourth quarter, and we've commented on that, just in terms of our look-forward expectations.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "10b73fcb-7c4e-4bcf-8a5d-9f7b6ee80a9f", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Thanks a lot.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jason Gabelman", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "f6a17aac-3a1c-423c-b14b-e398b6b02b73", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen and Company"}

section.text: Thanks, Jason.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "6db43ee0-43a6-4740-913b-505bd526949c", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Hi. Thank you for taking my question. I just wanted to ask about the LNG portfolio again. Could you clarify what proportion of your LNG sales are under long-term contracts, and what proportion are sold on a spot basis? The reason I ask is because your assets performing extremely well. In Qatar, Papua New Guinea and Golden Pass. So I just wondered if that has allowed you to sell some incremental spot cargos. So what proportion is under long-term contract?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Biraj Borkhataria", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "edd0adb5-93c5-4f63-b395-0e0b469b8489", "speaker_title": "Analyst at RBC Capital Markets"}

section.text: And if I could sneak a second one in, has there been a change to the 2022 Permian production. Kind of guidance in terms of growth. It looks slightly light relative to at least what I had -in mind. So, I was wondering if anything has changed there. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Biraj Borkhataria", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "edd0adb5-93c5-4f63-b395-0e0b469b8489", "speaker_title": "Analyst at RBC Capital Markets"}

section.text: So, the commentary I had made is in our LNG portfolio, about 80% of our volumes would be under long-term contract. And we're seeing the benefit of the timing lag because those contracts are typically -- the pricing is tied to crude but it has lagged kind of three to six months. So, we're seeing that benefit now coming through our realizations.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "aed4dfdd-84b2-47fe-9c62-d6cd555c2d5e", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Yeah, I would say on the Permian, one of the challenges there as over the years what we've been doing is working really hard to make sure we're maximizing the recovery of that resource. And I think we've talked before about some of the technology that we're bringing to bear to make sure that we are doing that in the most cost-advantaged way.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "a317bea9-9ced-442d-b3cd-1bc31643dcf8", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Obviously, as we go through that, we're optimizing and adjusting our development plans. That continues to be the case. So I expect this year, we will probably come in about 20% up on last year's growth, which was up 25% from the year before. So, still very solid growth in the Permian. And if you look more broadly, we expect basically to to meet the objectives that we talked about at the beginning year on overall production. If you look at what we had talked about at the beginning of the year for total production this year, and where we will end up, the delta there, of about 100,000 barrels a day, is really all driven by price entitlement and the fact that we're a much higher price environment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "a317bea9-9ced-442d-b3cd-1bc31643dcf8", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: So, we feel pretty good about the production growth that we're seeing across the portfolio. We've talked about the record production in the Permian, and Guyana is obviously performing very, very well with both of those boats running at above [Indecipherable] capacity.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "a317bea9-9ced-442d-b3cd-1bc31643dcf8", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Thank you. We'll take our next question from Alastair Syme with Citi.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Biraj Borkhataria", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "f3de4e50-eec2-4698-9316-50eeb0039df3", "speaker_title": "Analyst at RBC Capital Markets"}

section.text: Thank you. Kathy, can I come back to the very first question on energy products. And if you go back to the 8-K, at the close of the quarter, you suggested that industry margins would be a headwind of almost $3 billion. And today, the waterfall suggests that you've only really seen half of that. So I just wanted to understand -- I mean I don't recall there being a very big a difference between your industry margins -- indicated margins and your realized. So what does it do you think about the portfolio that's allowing you to see that such a degree...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alastair Syme", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "bb75c2c8-8b6d-48bd-9d44-b22b4a9f5fbc", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citi"}

section.text: And our impacts from, I'd say straight-up refining margins, came in kind of right in the middle of the range that we provided for the 8-K. And so beyond that, I mentioned we're seeing a positive beyond refining margins and aromatics margins. Overall revenue management and then end-to-end supply chain optimization and efficiency, which would include trading profit benefits. And so I'd say if you looked at quarter-to-quarter, what we've seen in energy products during the year, there's been a lot of volatility that's been basically tagged to the moving price environment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "9e8e155a-5908-451d-8af2-8f10a3d5fb79", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: If you look at that over a longer period of time, say, year-to-date, it looks, I would say, pretty normalized. And then we tried to give you information on things that were price timing stuff that occurred in the quarter, but over time, we would expect to be pretty neutral in. So, I mentioned specifically the program that we have, that we used derivatives to basically ensure ratable pricing of refinery and crude runs. Over time, we'd expect that to be neutral. You would have seen in the price timing impacts that that was about a $600 million favorable impact for the quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "9e8e155a-5908-451d-8af2-8f10a3d5fb79", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: So, I would say what goes on in terms of overall supply chain optimization and how we're trading around our physical footprint doesn't come through our results ratably every quarter. This quarter, it was obviously a lot stronger, but if you look at it over a long period of time, that benefit, that's embedded in the business, clearly shows through.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "9e8e155a-5908-451d-8af2-8f10a3d5fb79", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Do you think then forward, you would expect to be closer to the industry margins?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alastair Syme", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "02423e9e-e9f0-43d4-a55b-f4ef557cf75f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citi"}

section.text: It's really going to depend what the price environment is, what comes out of our trading portfolio in the fourth quarter. Obviously, I'd say, as you also looked at the overall benefits from the business, I'd say the big positive volume factor that we had was something that wouldn't get reflected in our 8-K because we had incredibly high throughput and utilization.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "bb5fb1c9-dd87-4193-b1cb-1955403a8b11", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: So what I tried to tell you is, if you put the price timing impacts to the side, we would start at about $5 billion in profit in energy products, and then it's going to be about what the -- how the market unfolds in the fourth quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "bb5fb1c9-dd87-4193-b1cb-1955403a8b11", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Yeah, I would just add to that, the 8-K was really looking at what the market factors are, and then to the extent that within the business we're working hard to improve upon that through the optimization that Kathy mentioned through revenue management across that entire value chain, and then trading in -- as trading moves and with the accounting rules as that booking happens with time, that comes in less than ratable. We saw that in this margin buckets this quarter. And that will move around as we move forward depending on the pricing environment that we're in.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "a9608746-27bb-4cf1-9e1a-c6b99eba80b6", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Thank you both for the clarification.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alastair Syme", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "a04c1c69-fb86-45fb-a29e-1c8bd179e2f4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citi"}

section.text: Hey, guys, good morning. Thanks for taking my question. Most of mine were asked, but if you could just maybe talk about the status of the refinery strikes in France. I know you had a couple of facilities that were impacted there that I believe are ramping back up. Where are we now with those facilities, and when do you expect them back in full? And do you think it actually has a meaningful impact on your 4Q results for Downstream?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John Royall", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "1d07554f-958e-4011-8455-6110c0a8ec0b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J. P. Morgan"}

section.text: Yeah, the -- so we reached an agreement with the workers' sometime ago and those refineries are basically going back through the startup process. When those refineries strike, we've got to bring those units down and free them of hydrocarbon. So that's a fairly thorough process of cleaning up the hydrocarbon -- clearing the hydrocarbons. So when we go to bring those back up, it's a fairly rigorous process of starting those back up to make sure we do that safely. So it takes some time to ramp things back up again. That's what the organization is working on.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "8befd1d8-18bc-4fe4-91ae-a9b8d31ee7af", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: I wouldn't expect it to have a meaningful impact. I mean obviously, in a market that is short any capacity come off -- that comes offline raises the overall prices within the industry, and so I think in net-net, that will probably -- there's some mitigation there with respect to our other refineries that are up and running. So, I don't think we'll see that in the results, frankly.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "8befd1d8-18bc-4fe4-91ae-a9b8d31ee7af", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Great. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John Royall", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "633d0fa7-cedf-4250-a0c6-32639519d451", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J. P. Morgan"}

section.text: Great. Thanks. Maybe, if I can follow-up on the Permian, and your activity level, Darren, expectations for U.S. supply growth in 2023, I would say probably has been falling a little bit across the board, at least partially because of constraints across service providers. As you look towards your 2023 program, how much do you anticipate stepping up activity levels in the Permian to achieve that program?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ryan Todd", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "41c343b5-e5d1-4bb8-af31-0abf1973bf09", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Piper Sandler"}

section.text: And if the market supports it, is there appetite or interest or even ability on your part to accelerate further. So, how much activity increase is based into the program and how tight do you see the market, Darren, in terms of your ability to kind of move around that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ryan Todd", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "41c343b5-e5d1-4bb8-af31-0abf1973bf09", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Piper Sandler"}

section.text: Yeah, sure. I think the points you making are good ones. The market is tight, and I think generally in the industry, there's not a lot of capacity as you look across the different steps required to bring on additional production.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "a0927dbd-1809-47c2-b8ad-6d8daa72429d", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: So, I think that is tight, that will, obvious with time, loosen up a little bit, but I think generally speaking for the industry, it's constrained. Obviously, every, every company will have different degrees of freedom in that space. We have some degrees of freedom there, but I would just say, we're staying very firmly grounded in our philosophy of making sure that the investments that we make generate high returns at low prices.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "a0927dbd-1809-47c2-b8ad-6d8daa72429d", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And so the capital discipline -- my definition of capital discipline is making sure that you spend money that's advantaged and has generated good returns, even in a down-cycle. We're going to stay grounded in that. And so anything that we do on the margin has to first and foremost, meet that criteria that is robust to a wide range of price environments, and that we'd be happy irrespective of what prices we're seeing out the window.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "a0927dbd-1809-47c2-b8ad-6d8daa72429d", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: We've got capacity to do that, frankly, in some space. So we will, on the margin, spend money to where we can see an opportunity to bring that on. But I wouldn't say, if you look at kind of a range of capex that we've provided over the years, we gave ourselves that range obviously, anticipated movement, not only within the year but across -- from one year to the next. And so, we feel pretty good that with -- in terms of the ranges that we've provided, our plans going forward are still very consistent with those ranges. And Kathy will spend more time talking about that in December when she takes you through the plan that we will get endorsed the Board next month.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "a0927dbd-1809-47c2-b8ad-6d8daa72429d", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Thanks, Darren.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ryan Todd", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "c9590f35-b444-4d10-92dc-ed917f971773", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Piper Sandler"}

section.text: You bet.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "29028102-99e5-4420-8980-79c86a12eaaf", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Hi. Good morning. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Cheng", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "854a5b9a-cb17-431f-9aea-9ccfdae4e92b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Scotiabank"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "2d2c04c4-2f38-44c2-b03e-01d2647c3a8f", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Darren and Kathy, just curious that -- I don't actually recall the product [Indecipherable] talked about trading as a major contributor to the results. Historically, I think the U.S. companies such as you and Shell tends to take a more conservative approach in trade comparing to your European cousins. So just curious that are we seeing the company having a somewhat change in trading strategy going forward, or this is just a unique circumstance?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Cheng", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "5d3fab3b-fcd3-48e3-b617-7655db6c66ea", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Scotiabank"}

section.text: And when we're talking about trading, what kind of trading are we referring to that's making a big contribution this quarter? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Paul Cheng", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "5d3fab3b-fcd3-48e3-b617-7655db6c66ea", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Scotiabank"}

section.text: Yeah,good morning, Paul. I'll touch on that and if Kathy has going anything to add, I'll let her jump in on the back. But what I would say is, I think we talked about this some years ago, that we were, when we moved to the value chain construction, when we combined our fuels marketing organization with a refining organization and start looking at optimizing value all along the the value chain, the trading organization became a much more relevant channel with respect to optimization. And so at that time, so back in 2018, we made the decision to invest more in trading and to change the approach there to optimize -- to act as a -- an optimization tool along all of our assets. And you may recall, we talked about asset-backed trading. And that continues to be an important part of the Product Solutions business and more specifically the Downstream element of the business as well as our Upstream crude.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "37f7038c-8503-4269-a04c-bf01ec0a71f5", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And so that organization has grown with time and continues to perform optimization function. I think what you're seeing this quarter, in particular, is the point that Kathy made, which is with the way you account for trading, that can be kind of noisy quarter-on-quarter, and then if you look longer term, you can see the value, kind of embedded within the businesses. And it is, I would say, very embedded within those businesses. So we don't break it out just because it is an asset-backed trading strategy. And therefore, the value derived through that obviously is through trading but obviously also through running our refineries reliably, having the product, and having the assets to support the arbitrages and the trade activities that create that value.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "37f7038c-8503-4269-a04c-bf01ec0a71f5", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And this quarter, we saw, with the way that the prices moved, a bigger chunk of it booked in the quarter. But I would just say, as you look at that over time, it is a meaningful contributor to the value equation in our Downstream value chain.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "37f7038c-8503-4269-a04c-bf01ec0a71f5", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Yeah, and the only thing I would add to that is, we are trying to also tell you that there are some impacts that, over time, we expect to be neutral. So the fact that we used derivatives to ensure ratable pricing of our refinery crude runs, sometimes that's going to give us a positive in a quarter, sometimes that's going to give us a negative in a quarter, over time, it should be neutral.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "821b8942-770f-4ae5-957f-70c5601f2519", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And that's the best way I can try to get out with a price timing.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 70, "uuid": "a6578686-bdf4-4b35-ad8f-1fb078184a63", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: That's great. Darren, just curious that the trading also contributed to the strong natural gas price realization that you record or that that has nothing to do with that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Cheng", "section_number": 71, "uuid": "60f76ad4-5ef1-412d-9e0c-6df1867f1782", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Scotiabank"}

section.text: We also have trading that we would be doing within our Upstream business. And so, you can see that -- some of those impacts reported in our results but that -- we have spot, I would say, exposure, and we do trade around that as well, very embedded in the business. It's not really as big a factor is what we would have seen obviously in energy products.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 72, "uuid": "c21fff1c-9943-40cf-b881-32f244249763", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Cheng", "section_number": 73, "uuid": "a259c807-fda1-40ab-ba70-2ced81e486b0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Scotiabank"}

section.text: Good morning, all, and thanks for the time. My quick question is just on costs, specifically could you speak to your thoughts for 2023 on OFS in place and other rising cost, particularly in your two highest return areas, the Permian and Guyana?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Neal Dingmann", "section_number": 75, "uuid": "b0c2df58-056c-4eaf-aec7-548d02ed72db", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Truist Securities"}

section.text: Yeah, I'll touch on that, Neil. I mean, obviously, we're subject to the same broad market forces that everyone is seeing out there, and so, inflationary pressures across a number of our sectors and activities. I think a couple of things, one is as you will recall, as we went through the pandemic and the downturn, we were -- took a very concerted effort to work with our contracting partners and the recognition that we would be back that we would longer-term be running rigs and putting pipe in the ground, and so try to enter into contracts that reflected that longer-term objective. And that has helped manage some of the inflationary impacts and that we kind of set some contracts back in the downturn with a commitment to continue to spend money going forward. And so that's been an offset.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 76, "uuid": "b13ecbc7-efc9-4ac0-ae2b-3d19217080ac", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And then of course the organization, with all the changes that we've been making, you remember we took our Upstream organization from seven-plus businesses down to one, and organized very, very differently, we centralized a lot of the functions, really trying to harness our scale and leverage the purchasing power that we have, and then cut our cost out. So all those efforts to become more efficient and more effective in the marketplace and reduce cost are having a significant impact.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 76, "uuid": "b13ecbc7-efc9-4ac0-ae2b-3d19217080ac", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: We mentioned in the earnings release that to-date, we have $6.4 billion of structural savings versus 2019, and we're well on our way to meeting the objective we set by end 2023 of $9 billion in structural savings. So that's helping to offset some of those inflationary pressures. And then on top of that, with decentralized organizations and more effectively leveraging the scale, we're getting what I would call, what we term as kind of short term efficiencies, purchasing power, however you want to think about that, that we don't put in the structural bucket but actually helps us to offset costs.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 76, "uuid": "b13ecbc7-efc9-4ac0-ae2b-3d19217080ac", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And so, we challenged ourselves to deliver on our expense budget for the year, and to offset inflation. The organization is doing a pretty good job at that. I think, we'll be within rounding with respect to that. And then next year, the organization is very focused on using the opportunities that have been created through the restructuring of our business to offset those inflationary pressures, and we're going to stretch ourselves, see how much of that we can do.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 76, "uuid": "b13ecbc7-efc9-4ac0-ae2b-3d19217080ac", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Great details. Thank you, all.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Neal Dingmann", "section_number": 77, "uuid": "64b26c26-0c88-4ed6-ab86-764ffdd6fd89", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Truist Securities"}

section.text: Katy, we have time for one more question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jennifer Driscoll", "section_number": 78, "uuid": "41f83ebf-09a5-45d8-9a83-29e62cedc7e7", "speaker_title": "Vice President of Investor Relations at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Yeah, good morning. Maybe just to follow-up on the capacity question that was asked earlier, but rather than just focus on services capacity in a particular region or something like that, Darren, I was curious, if you look at tightness, be it LNG refining et cetera, what do you think it takes or do you believe that the capacity exists for the world to move forward to do what it needs to do over the next, say two to three years to add capacity or do you see it as a situation where, they probably is no other option but to curtail demand for some period of time. Just kind of a macro question, but you brought it up in the intro and it's kind of picking at me here as to what's the way out of this mess.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Roger Read", "section_number": 80, "uuid": "88a10678-aaf5-4186-a8a2-06be624fecd2", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo Securities"}

section.text: Yeah, well, thanks, Roger. I think the industry has been historically pretty good at flexing on capacity to meet the demand. And so, I'm optimistic that with time, the markets -- and we've proven this, I think over the years, that the markets will come back into balance. But it is a function of time. I think in the short-term, everyone will squeeze what they can. Certainly, you've seen us pushing as hard as we can to make sure that we're running reliably and we're getting product to the marketplace to meet that need in the market. I know everyone else is trying to do the same. So I think that piece of it is sweating all the existing assets as hard as you can is going to help in the short-term. But longer -- but more structurally, it's just a function of getting these projects developed and on track.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 81, "uuid": "2a29ccf8-b6cb-4a79-b9bf-835c740f8059", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: I mean fortunately for us, we've had a very healthy pipeline of projects that have been in work. And so, it's not -- we're not out trying to find something to work on. We're basically focused on delivering the pipeline that we've got, an we're bringing on, as we talked about, we brought in a Coral floating LNG added in Mozambique this quarter. That's additional capacity. We're progressing investments in Papua New Guinea, we've got Golden Pass here in the U.S. It's progressing a very large LNG export terminal that should come online in 2024. That's going to probably increase the exports out of Gulf Coast by 20%.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 81, "uuid": "2a29ccf8-b6cb-4a79-b9bf-835c740f8059", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: So, I think the capacities there is just a function of the time it takes to build these very significant projects. And I would also tell you that if you look at on the crude side of the equation, we're making very good progress with the next spoke and the Guyana. We continue to believe we're going to bring that in a little bit early. And we're progressing the ones after that. So I think, capacity is there, it's -- the challenge is executing efficiently, so that you're getting -- you're spending your capital efficiently, and then doing it in a way that brings it on -- expedite fashion which is what we're focused on doing.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 81, "uuid": "2a29ccf8-b6cb-4a79-b9bf-835c740f8059", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: And then just the one thing I'd add is on the demand-side. I think all companies that can, are looking to conserve, especially LNG, so that it can be there for other use. So across our footprint in Europe, we've already kind of switched over 65% of our use of LNG to other fuel sources, so that it can be there for other use, and I expect that other industry players are doing the same.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kathryn A. Mikells", "section_number": 82, "uuid": "cf86dd96-ec71-4c5e-bad0-e8bc96064f09", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Great. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Roger Read", "section_number": 83, "uuid": "86cdec56-3f61-4c32-a2ee-6867ca4b8025", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo Securities"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Darren Woods", "section_number": 84, "uuid": "2fa4705e-4da4-4855-b257-3712762740c2", "speaker_title": "Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Thanks, Roger. Thanks, everybody, for your questions today. We will post the transcript of the Q&A session on our investor website early next week.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jennifer Driscoll", "section_number": 85, "uuid": "65a2b312-8852-4efb-aea6-a69bd5f171d0", "speaker_title": "Vice President of Investor Relations at Exxon Mobil"}

section.text: Have a nice weekend, everyone, and let me turn it back to Katy to conclude our call. Katy?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jennifer Driscoll", "section_number": 85, "uuid": "65a2b312-8852-4efb-aea6-a69bd5f171d0", "speaker_title": "Vice President of Investor Relations at Exxon Mobil"}

title: Q&A for XOM (Exxon Mobil) on 10/28/22 8:30 AM ET
